com.tailf.jnc
Class ConfDSession

java.lang.Object
  com.tailf.jnc.NetconfSession
      com.tailf.jnc.ConfDSession

public class ConfDSession
extends NetconfSession

An extended NETCONF session class, with capabilities that ConfD supports.

ConfD supports the following optional, non-standard capabilities:

  • actions
  • transactions
  • with-defaults
The :with-defaults capability introduces an attribute 'with-defaults' which can be used in the 'rpc' element when the operation is 'get', 'get-config', or 'copy-config', to control if default values are returned by the NETCONF agent or not. If 'with-defaults' is "true", default values are included. If 'with-defaults' is "false", default values are not included.

The :action capability introduces one new rpc method which is used to invoke actions (methods) defined in the data model. When an action is invoked, the instance on which the action is invoked is explicitly identified by an hierarchy of configuration or state data.

Here's a simple example which resets an interface. 

 <rpc message-id="101"
      xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0">
   <action xmlns="http://tail-f.com/ns/netconf/actions/1.0">
      <data>
          <interfaces xmlns="http://example.com/interfaces/1.0">
            <interface>
              <name>eth0</name>
              <reset/>
            </interface>
          </interfaces>
        </data>
      </action>
    </rpc>
 
 <rpc-reply message-id="101"
             xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0">
      <ok/>
 </rpc-reply>

The :transactions capability introduces four new rpc methods which are used to control a two-phase commit transaction on the NETCONF server. The normal edit-config operation is used to write data in the transaction, but the modifications are not applied until an explicit commit-transaction is sent.

A typical sequence of operations looks like this: 

 C                           S
 |                           |
 |  capability exchange      |
 |-------------------------->|
 |<------------------------->|
 |                           |
 |   <start-transaction>     |
 |-------------------------->|
 |<--------------------------|
 |         <ok/>             |
 |                           |
 |     <edit-config>         |
 |-------------------------->|
 |<--------------------------|
 |         <ok/>             |
 |                           |
 |  <prepare-transaction>    |
 |-------------------------->|
 |<--------------------------|
 |         <ok/>             |
 |                           |
 |   <commit-transaction>    |
 |-------------------------->|
 |<--------------------------|
 |         <ok/>             |
 |                           |

See Also:
NetconfSession

Method Detail

setWithDefaults

public void setWithDefaults(boolean value)
                     throws JNCException
Set the 'with-defaults' to 'true' or 'false'. This capability is valid for get, get-config, and copy-config, to control if defualt values are returned by the NETCONF agent or not. If this value is 'true', default values are included. If this value is 'false', default valus are not included.

Parameters:
value - Value for with-defaults.
Throws:
JNCException

action

public Element action(Element data)
               throws JNCException,
                      java.io.IOException
Action capability. An action that does not return any result value, replies with the standard 'ok' element. If a result value is returned, it is encapsulated within a returned 'data' element.

Parameters:
data - element tree with action-data
Throws:
JNCException
java.io.IOException

startTransaction

public void startTransaction(int datastore)
                      throws JNCException,
                             java.io.IOException
Starts a transaction towards a configuration datastore. There can be a single ongoing transaction at any time.

When a transaction has been started, the client can send any NETCONF operation, but any edit-config operation sent from the client must speify the same target as the start-transaction. If the server receives and edit-config with another target, an error must be returned with an error-tag set to "invalid-value".

The modifications sent in the edit-config operations are not immediately applied to the configuration datastore. Instead they are kept in the transaction state of the server. The transaction state is only applied when a commit-transaction is received.

The client sends a prepare-transaction when all modifications have been sent.

Parameters:
datastore - The datastore. One of NetconfSession.RUNNING, NetconfSession.CANDIDATE, NetconfSession.STARTUP
Throws:
JNCException
java.io.IOException
See Also:
startTransaction(int), commitTransaction(), abortTransaction()

prepareTransaction

public void prepareTransaction()
                        throws JNCException,
                               java.io.IOException
Prepares the transaction state for commit. The server may reject the prepare request for any reason, for example due to lack of resources or if the combined changes would result in an invalid configuration datastore.

After a successful prepare-transaction, the next transaction related rpc operation must be commit-transaction or abort-transaction. Note that an edit-config cannot be sent before the transaction is either committed or aborted.

Care must be taken by the server to make sure that if prepare-transaction succeeds then the commit-transaction should not fail, since this might result in an inconsistent distributed state. Thus, prepare-transaction should allocate any resources needed to make sure the commit-transaction will succeed.

Throws:
JNCException
java.io.IOException
See Also:
startTransaction(int), commitTransaction(), abortTransaction()

commitTransaction

public void commitTransaction()
                       throws JNCException,
                              java.io.IOException
Applies the changes made in the transaction to the configuration datatore. The transaction is closed after a commit-transaction.

Throws:
JNCException
java.io.IOException
See Also:
startTransaction(int), prepareTransaction(), abortTransaction()

abortTransaction

public void abortTransaction()
                      throws JNCException,
                             java.io.IOException
Aborts the ongoing transaction, and all pending changes are discarded. abort-transaction can be given at any time during an ongoing transaction.

Throws:
JNCException
java.io.IOException
See Also:
startTransaction(int), prepareTransaction(), commitTransaction()
